unnormalised: The first time I saw a price of ₹99, I thought it was a typo. My grandma, visiting from our ancestral village near Patna, was even more confused. She'd come to Mumbai for Diwali and wanted to buy a saree online. I showed her a beautiful Banarasi silk one on Flipkart, but the ₹999 price tag made her skeptical. "Yeh kya hai? Itna kam kaise?" she asked, convinced it was either a scam or the saree was damaged.
normalised: The first time I saw a price of rupee ninety nine, I thought it was a typo. My grandma, visiting from our ancestral village near Patna, was even more confused. She'd come to Mumbai for Diwali and wanted to buy a saree online. I showed her a beautiful Banarasi silk one on Flipkart, but the rupee nine hundred and ninety nine price tag made her skeptical. "Yeh kya hai? Itna kam kaise?" she asked, convinced it was either a scam or the saree was damaged.

unnormalised: Explaining the psychology behind pricing in e-commerce to someone used to traditional bargaining was a challenge. I told her how these "ending in 9" prices, like ₹499 or ₹1999, made things seem cheaper. She still insisted on checking the reviews – all 4.5 stars and 2k+ ratings – before adding it to her cart. The actual cost, including delivery charges (Rs. 50), came to ₹1049.
normalised: Explaining the psychology behind pricing in e-commerce to someone used to traditional bargaining was a challenge. I told her how these "ending in nine" prices, like rupee four hundred and ninety nine or rupee one thousand nine hundred and ninety nine, made things seem cheaper. She still insisted on checking the reviews – all four point five stars and two thousand plus ratings – before adding it to her cart. The actual cost, including delivery charges (rupees fifty), came to rupee one thousand and forty nine.

unnormalised: Then came the payment. I showed her all the options - UPI, net banking, credit card, and even cash on delivery (COD). She refused to use my credit card. "Yeh sab online fraud hota hai," she warned, recalling stories from the village of people losing lakhs to cyber scams. She opted for COD, insisting on checking the saree thoroughly before paying.
normalised: Then came the payment. I showed her all the options - U-P-I, net banking, credit card, and even cash on delivery (C-O-D). She refused to use my credit card. "Yeh sab online fraud hota hai," she warned, recalling stories from the village of people losing lakhs to cyber scams. She opted for C-O-D, insisting on checking the saree thoroughly before paying.

unnormalised: A few days later, the delivery guy arrived. Grandma examined the saree under the brightest light in the house, scrutinizing every inch of the silk. After a thorough inspection, she finally handed over the ₹1049. She even haggled with the delivery guy for a Rs. 10 discount! He, of course, politely declined.

unnormalised: The next day, she proudly wore the saree for Diwali puja. Seeing her smile, I realised the real value wasn't just the ₹999 price tag, but the joy it brought her. And even though online shopping seemed foreign to her at first, she'd successfully navigated the e-commerce world, armed with her traditional wisdom and a healthy dose of skepticism.
